content.description:
This climb is all the way at the left end of the cliff. It can be identified by some chossy left-facing flakes/corners at the start that don't look too appealing, and some nicer looking cracks at the top. Start up the choss, being careful not to break anything off. Get to a ledge then enjoy some nice short cracks that end all too soon as you top out.

No anchor at the top. There is a thick dead tree several feet back from the edge Â you could belay from; it was bomber as of July 2021 but it's dead so use your judgement. Walk off left.
content.location: All the way at the left end of the cliff. Look for choss at the start and some short nice looking cracks above that.

content.description:
This is an obvious crack that goes to the top of the wall. It can be identified by a scary, detached-looking block near the bottom. The block seemed solid when I pulled on it but use your judgement.

No anchor at the top. There is a thick dead tree several feet back from the edge you could belay from; it was bomber as of July 2021 but it's dead so use your judgement. Walk off left.
content.protection: Cams and nuts. I didn't place anything larger than a BD 0.5 but you could place cams larger than that.
content.location: Pretty far on the left end of the cliff. Look for the detached block in the obvious crack that goes to the top of the cliff.

content.description:
Climb a short fingercrack/layback to get to a large ledge (or scramble around left; but you should do the direct start as it's fun and protects well). From the large ledge, climb a left facing corner to a smaller ledge. From this smaller ledge you have 2 options. Go left following 2 bolts to climb "Nothing's Shocking" 5.9. Go right following more bolts to climb "Stop Making Sense" 5.10b.

Bolt anchors with rings at the top.
content.protection: Cams (the corner gets wide so bring a 3, maybe even a 4) plus 2 bolts. 2 bolt anchor at the top
content.location: Look for a short splitter finger crack in a block below a large ledge; there is a horizontal break halfway up that block. And the big left facing corner above that ledge.

content.description:
When I did this route, I think I started too far left. I followed some easy but unprotected terrain up and to the right until I encountered the bolts that mark this route. However, I think the correct start is at a right-facing corner that goes up and leftwards; there is a cool looking flake sticking out of this corner. Follow the corner up and left, continuing up and left after the corner ends. Eventually you will start moving back right when you see a bolt. Follow 2 bolts past some delicate, insecure climbing; classic granite trickery.

Going straight up instead of left then back right is "Barefoot Crow Right", also 5.10a. Blank looking slab with 4 bolts. It shares an anchor with Barefoot Crow Left so you can TR it after leading the left climb.

2 bolt anchor at the top.
content.protection: I only placed a few small cams besides the bolts, however I started at the wrong spot. Trad gear plus 2 bolts. 2 bolt anchor at the top.
content.location: Start at a small right-facing corner that diagonals up and left and has a cool flake sticking out of it. To your left you will see a large block on the ground that forms a right-facing corner. Don't start on top of that block, as I did accidentally.

content.description:
The large, low-angle right-facing corner that runs all the way up the cliff. It has some nice easy corner climbing at the bottom and the top, however it gets dirty and vegetated in the middle. Still, it's an aesthetic, obvious line that tops out the cliff, so it's worth climbing.

I did not find and anchors at the top however I topped out in darkness so I may have missed them. Gear anchor then walkoff. I walked off left; it may be possible to walk off right.
content.location: Locate the big obvious corner just to the left of the big gully that splits the cliff in two. At the start of the corner, there are some nice looking cracks of the left wall.
